health_outcome_short: Increased hyperactivity / attention problems in children when these mixes are consumed regularly.
vulnerable_groups: Children (especially those with high intake or ADHD tendencies).
mechanism_notes: Mixtures of azo dyes + benzoate associated with higher hyperactivity scores in RCTs; exact neurochemical mechanism unclear.
typical_food_context: Brightly coloured soft drinks, juices, sweets, ice lollies.

health_outcome_short: Formation of benzene (carcinogen) in benzoate+vitamin C drinks under certain conditions; risk usually low but monitored.
vulnerable_groups: General consumers (especially children drinking affected soft drinks).
mechanism_notes: In acidic, oxygenated drinks, ascorbate can catalyse decarboxylation of benzoate to benzene; reaction enhanced by heat/light/metal ions.
typical_food_context: Some soft drinks, fruit-flavoured beverages, diet sodas with vitamin C.

health_outcome_short: Increased colorectal cancer risk from nitrosamine formation in nitrite-cured processed meats.
vulnerable_groups: General population, especially high processed-meat eaters; vulnerable: everyone (strong epidemiological link).
mechanism_notes: Nitrite forms nitrosating species in acidic gut; reacts with amines in meat to form carcinogenic N-nitroso compounds; haem iron promotes these reactions and oxidative stress.
typical_food_context: Cured/processed meats (bacon, ham, sausages, hot dogs, cured fish).

health_outcome_short: Can trigger bronchospasm, wheezing, asthma attacks or urticaria in sulphite-sensitive individuals.
vulnerable_groups: Asthmatics (about 3â€“10% show sulphite sensitivity), some allergic individuals.
mechanism_notes: In sensitive people, released SO2 from ingested sulphites can provoke reflex bronchoconstriction and pseudo-allergic mast-cell activation.
typical_food_context: Dried fruit, wine, beer, some juices, pickles, shrimp, potato products, salad bars.

health_outcome_short: High combined intake of multiple artificial sweeteners associated with metabolic dysregulation and higher CVD risk in cohorts.
vulnerable_groups: High consumers of diet drinks/foods, people with obesity or diabetes relying heavily on non-sugar sweeteners, children on 'sugar-free' diets.
mechanism_notes: Different non-sugar sweeteners alter gut microbiota and metabolic signalling; higher total intake associated with increased cardiovascular events.
typical_food_context: Diet/zero sodas, sugar-free desserts, 'light' yoghurts, tabletop sweetener blends.

health_outcome_short: In animals, low-dose emulsifiers plus high-fat diet promote gut inflammation, microbiota changes and metabolic syndrome; emerging human evidence.
vulnerable_groups: People with high intake of ultra-processed foods; individuals predisposed to IBD or metabolic syndrome.
mechanism_notes: Emulsifiers thin the mucus layer and change microbiota; bacteria encroach epithelium causing inflammation; high-fat diets amplify endotoxaemia and metabolic stress.
typical_food_context: Ice cream, creamy desserts, sauces, processed bread, ready meals with multiple emulsifiers.

health_outcome_short: Caffeine with high sugar load causes higher glucose and insulin spikes and can acutely stress cardiovascular and metabolic systems.
vulnerable_groups: Teens/young adults using energy drinks; people with prediabetes/insulin resistance; caffeine-sensitive individuals.
mechanism_notes: Caffeine increases catecholamines and hepatic glucose output; sugar causes rapid glycaemic rise; together create larger glucose/insulin excursions and BP/HR changes.
typical_food_context: Energy drinks, sugary coffee drinks, sugary colas.

health_outcome_short: Energy drinks with caffeine+taurine can cause greater increases in blood pressure/heart rate vs caffeine alone in some trials; concern in heavy users.
vulnerable_groups: Adolescents and young adults consuming multiple energy drinks; people with heart disease or hypertension.
mechanism_notes: Caffeine blocks adenosine and raises catecholamines; taurine modulates calcium and cardiac electrophysiology; together may alter hemodynamics more than caffeine alone.
typical_food_context: Energy drinks, energy 'shots', some pre-workout products.

health_outcome_short: High sodium plus high inorganic phosphate intake amplifies hypertension and cardiovascular/kidney stress.
vulnerable_groups: High processed-food consumers; especially chronic kidney disease patients and other high-risk groups.
mechanism_notes: Phosphate additives raise FGF23 leading to sympathetic activation and vascular damage; salt raises blood volume and BP; together overload BP and kidney regulation.
typical_food_context: Processed meats, processed cheeses, instant noodles, fast food, colas and many ultra-processed savoury foods.
